In practice hash tables are usually much much faster (orders of magnitude) than binary search trees for large datasets. A binary tree has to jump through log_2(n) random memory indirections to get to the data. A hash table can usually go directly to the data. Accessing memory is usually way more expensive than computation these days. Test it out and see for yourself.

@Robadob: your check fails for something like "\\\\*" - a backslash (escaped with another backslash) repeated zero or more times. It's not enough to check for special characters with no backslashes before them - you need to check for special characters preceded by an even number (possibly zero) of backslashes. Personally, I'd not try to express that with a regexp, but write a simple single-pass algorithm that checks for special characters while keeping track of the length of the most recent run of backslashes.

@JohnDibling is correct -- there were proposals to add hashing-based containers to C++98, but they came after the cutoff for adding new features, so they were delayed until the next (major) revision of the standard. That said, at that time, cache usage wasn't nearly as crucial as it is now, and memory was more constrained so most in-memory collections were small enough that hash tables didn't necessarily provide a huge advantage anyway.

They were implemented long before C++11, as hash_set etc. in the STL and unordered_set etc. in TR1 (and Boost). Unfortunately, the 1998 committee didn't have time to include them in that standard library, and there wasn't a major library update until 2011, so it took until then to bless them with officialdom.

@PascalCuoq Just the opposite: "centuries" is an understatement when it comes to solving an NP complete problem. On the other hand: if the analyser should warn anytime more than one object might be modified without the modifications being sequenced, then it's quite doable, in linear time. @PascalCuoq  When mere compiling takes hours (common with modern software) then scientific proof that the program is correct may take centuries. False positive warnings of such tools (when it can't prove either way) more often annoy than aid.

@Enrico: The io_service is thread safe, so there is no need for a strand. However, a strand would provide the same result with some extra overhead. A strand maintains a queue of handlers, only posting one of its handler into its io_service at a time via dispatch(). In the context of the above example, dispatch() will delegate to post(). For more details on strands and when they are needed, it may be worth reading this answer.

Also thank you for pointing out that the correct pattern would be using two separate io_service for the GUI amd the worker thread, and NOT a single io_service shared between the two threads. My knowledge of Boost Asio is quite basic and your answer shed some light on its correct use.

What you got was probably Frame 5 too long (NNN bytes), for some value of "NNN". "NNN" is what dumpcap read as the "captured length" of the packet in the per-packet header (hdr->incl_len), and it must be <= 65535. If it's a bit larger, you need to write smaller packets; if it's a lot larger, it might be that you're writing the packet header wrong.

The documentation clearly (for the most part, anyway) describes successful return values from API calls, and how to know if they succeeded or not; if you don't properly check and just make assumptions....
